1052.description: The Italian peninsula extending northward to the Alps as recognized by the Romans.
1052.title: Italia

1273.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 1 I1 Scythia
1273.title: Scythia

1332.description: Thessalia (Thessaly) was a region of ancient Greece.
1332.title: Thessalia

197544.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 20 D6 Tauris Ins.
197544.title: Tauris Ins.

240868.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 24 unlocated Attica/Bergida
240868.title: Attica/Bergida

422824.description: Alba Longa, located in the Alba Hills southeast of Rome, was the chief city and founder of the Latin League. Conflict with Rome caused Alba's destruction in the seventh century BC. The legendary history of Romulus and Remus connects them to the royal lineage of the city.
422824.title: Alba Longa?

422863.description: The Campus Martius or "field of Mars" is the name given to the level ground between the slopes of the Capitoline, the Quirinal, and Pincian hills, and the Tiber river.
422863.title: Campus Martius

422914.description: An ancient town of Latium located at the headwaters of the Allia river, very close to the territory of the Sabines, Crustumerium figures in Rome's early history. The Romans conquered the site in 500 BC and formed the tribus Crustumina or Clustumina  in 471 BC.
422914.title: Crustumerium

422923.description: Fidenae was an ancient city of Latium.
422923.title: Fidenae

422960.description: An ancient city of Latium. Founded, according to Virgil, by Aeneas.
422960.title: Lavinium

423025.description: The capital of the Roman Republic and Empire.

properties.description: Location as derived from Google Earth, specifically the Temple of Vesta in the Roman Forum.
properties.title: Temple of Vesta

423025.title: Roma

423080.description: The Tiber river is the third-longest river of the Italian peninsula, flowing 406 km (252 mi) from the Apennine Mountains to the Tyrrhenian Sea.
423080.title: Tiberis (river)

423116.description: An important city of South Etruria located north-northwest of Rome, Veii was eventually sacked by the Romans in 396 BC. The ancient city covered some 180 ha.

properties.title: location of archaeological area of Villa Campetti
location of archaeological area of Piano della Comunità
location of archaeological area of Macchia Grande

properties.description: The site of the arx of ancient Veii
properties.title: Piazza d'Armi

properties.description: The Portonaccio sanctuary of Etruscan Veii
properties.title: Portonaccio sanctuary

423116.title: Veii

432712.description: A volcanic crater lake located within the Phlegraean Fields, Avernus served a major ritual role for ancient Romans and Greeks a they viewed it as an entrance to Hades.
432712.title: Avernus L.

438675.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 44 unlocated Amyclae
438675.title: Amyclae

438703.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 44 unlocated Caenina
438703.title: Caenina

442633.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 45 A4 Leucosia Ins.
442633.title: Leucosia Ins.

462157.description: Charybdis was a sea monster that was rationalized in the form of a whirlpool located in the Strait of Messina.
462157.title: Charybdis

462492.description: Sicily is the largest island in the Mediterranean Sea and has been the site of human habitation since ca. 8,000 BC. In historical terms Sicily has seen important settlement activity connected to numerous culture groups - Punic, Carthaginian, Greek, Roman, Vandalic, Ostrogothic, Byzantine, Arabic, and Norman.
462492.title: Sicilia (island)

481787.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 49 B3 Chaonia
481787.title: Chaonia

491677.description: Olympus M. is the highest mountain in Greece, located in the Olympus Range.
491677.title: Olympus M.

501386.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 51 G4 Chersonesus
501386.title: Chersonesus

501434.description: A narrow strait of northwestern Turkey that connect the Aegean Sea to Propontis (Sea of Marmara).
501434.title: Hellespontus

511337.description: Nicomedia was founded in 712/11 BC as a Megarian colony named Astacus and was rebuilt by Nicomedes I of Bithynia in 264 BC. The city was an important administrative center of the Roman Empire.
511337.title: Nicomedia

530871.description: An ancient region that included northwest parts of modern Greece and the southern tip of modern Albania.
530871.title: Epirus

530905.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 54 C5 Ithaca
530905.title: Ithaca

540714.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 55 E4 Cithaeron M.
540714.title: Cithaeron M.

540723.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 55 D3 Daulis
540723.title: Daulis

540726.description: The ancient pan-Hellenic sanctuary of Delphi in Greece, seat of the oracle of Apollo.
540726.title: Delphi

541063.description: Plataea is an ancient city of Boeotia, located south of Thebes. In 479 BC Plataea was the site of the Battle of Plataea, in which an allied Greek army defeated the Persians. Plataea was destroyed in the Peloponnesian War by Thebes and Sparta in 427 BC and rebuilt in 386 BC.
541063.title: Plataea

541138.description: The ancient city of Thebes in Boeotia (modern Greece).
541138.title: Thebai/Thebae

550595.description: An ancient city of northwest Anatolia with occupation ranging from the Bronze Age to the Roman period.
550595.title: Ilium/Troia

550812.description: An important ancient settlement, located at modern Bergama in Turkey. It was first described in Xenophon's Anabasis and was later used as a treasury under Lysimachus. Pergamum became the administrative capital and principal city of the Attalid kingdom and dynasty (282-133 BCE) and was briefly the first capital of the Roman province of Asia. It later was a seat of a christian bishopric and is listed in Revelation as one of the seven churches of Asia. It was inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2014 under "Pergamon and its Multi-Layered Cultural Landscape".

properties.description: The Great Altar of Zeus, constructed during the first half of the 2nd century BC, is a monumental altar on a high platform, with two projecting wings; its Hellenistic Baroque sculptural program includes a high-relief Gigantomachy around the outside of the building and an interior frieze depicting the story of the mythical hero Telephos
properties.title: The Great Altar at Pergamon

550812.title: Pergamum

550919.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 56 E2 Thebe
550919.title: Thebe

570102.description: The ancient region of Arcadia comprised the highlands at the center of the Peloponnese.
570102.title: Arcadia

570182.description: The ancient Greek and Roman city of Corinth, located in the Peloponnese, Greece. Also known today as Archaia Korinthos and not to be confused with the nearby modern town.

properties.description: The second temple of Apollo at Corinth whose reconstructed remains are visible on the site today.
properties.title: Center of the Temple of Apollo at Corinth

570182.title: Corinthus/Korinthos

570220.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 58 A2 Elis
570220.title: Elis

570290.description: Herakleia was an ancient settlement of Pisatis in Elis, some 40 or 50 stades from Olympia.
570290.title: Herakleia

570406.description: Lacedaemon/Laconia is a region comprising the south-eastern part of the Peloponnese.
570406.title: Lacedaemon/Laconia

570459.description: Mantineia/Antigoneia was an ancient settlement in Greece most noted for being the site of two major battles. The First Battle of Mantinea was the largest land battle of the Peloponnesian War (418 BC) and the Second Battle of Mantinea brought an end to Theban hegemony (362 BC).
570459.title: Mantineia/Antigoneia

570468.description: Megara was an important ancient city of Greece, located in the northern part of the the Isthmus of Corinth opposite the island of Salamis.
570468.title: Megara

570491.description: Mycenae was an ancient settlement of the Argolid, with the earliest occupation evident ca. 2900 BC. As the eponymous site of the Mycenaean culture of the Aegean Bronze Age, the site flourishes as a fortified citadel during the mid to late second millennium BC. In the first millennium BC, the site experiences a revival of fortunes, although by Strabo's time the settlement had vanished.

properties.description: A Bronze Age tholos tomb with a corbeled dome and monumental ashlar facade on the Panagitsa Hill at Mycenae.
properties.title: Treasury of Atreus

properties.description: Grave Circle A encloses a royal cemetery within the walls of the citadel of Mycenae; inside it are six shaft graves constructed around 1600 BC
properties.title: Grave Circle A at Mycenae

570491.title: Mycenae

570531.description: Ancient sanctuary of Zeus and home of the ancient Olympic games.

properties.description: Palaestra in the sanctuary of Zeus at Olympia
properties.title: Palaestra at Olympia
Center of the Temple of Zeus at Olympia

570531.title: Olympia

570668.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 58 D2 Sicyon/Demetrias
570668.title: Sicyon/Demetrias

570685.description: Sparta was a prominent city-state (polis) of ancient Greece.

properties.description: Archaic temple dedicated to Artemis Orthia within the sanctuary of this goddess at Sparta. The site contained rich deposits of votives and masks.
properties.title: Temple of Artemis Orthia

570685.title: Sparta

579885.description: A major Greek city-state and the principal city of Attika.

properties.description: Theatre on the south slope of the Acropolis.
properties.title: Theatre of Dionysus Eleuthereus

properties.description: Temple of Hephaistos located on the northwest side of the Agora of Athens
properties.title: Hephaisteion

properties.description: The Stoa of Zeus Eleutherios was built on the west side of the Agora of Athens between 430-425 BC, in honor of Zeus "of Freedom"; the stoa, Doric in its external order, housed the shields of Athenians who had died fighting for the city
properties.title: Stoa of Zeus (Eleutherios)

properties.description: A district of ancient Athens located northwest of the Acropolis, the Kerameikos takes its name from the potters' workshops in the area; the portion of the district lying outside the Dipylon Gate served as a necropolis.
properties.title: Kerameikos

properties.description: The Erechtheion is a temple on the Athenian Acropolis dedicated to Athena Polias and other deities and heroes; the temple is of the Ionic order with several distinctive features, including its famous caryatid porch
properties.title: The Erechtheion

properties.description: The acropolis of the ancient city
properties.title: Acropolis of Athens

properties.description: The marketplace of the ancient city
properties.title: Agora of Athens

579885.title: Athenae

579888.description: Historical region of Greece, centered on the Attic Peninsula.
579888.title: Attica

579889.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 59 B1 Aulis
579889.title: Aulis

580021.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 59 C2 Marathon
580021.title: Marathon

580101.description: Salamis is the largest island of the Saronic Gulf.

properties.description: Coordinates after BAtlas; verified in Google Earth 2013 with reference to Wikipedia.
properties.title: location of Salamis Ins.

580101.title: Salamis Ins.

580599.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 59 C2 unnamed aqueduct (Athens from N)
580599.title: Untitled

599564.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 61 F2 Caria
599564.title: Caria

599753.description: Latmos M. (Beşparmak Mountains) run east-west along the north shore of the former Latmian Gulf on the coast of Caria.
599753.title: Latmos M.

609502.description: Phrygia was an ancient kingdom of west-central Anatolia.
609502.title: Phrygia

639073.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 65 G4 Ptolemais
639073.title: Ptolemais

707596.description: Located on Cyprus, Paphos has been inhabited since the Neolithic period and was an important cult center of Aphrodite.
707596.title: (Palai)Paphos

736963.description: A city and capital of Ancient Egypt that remained an important center for most of Egyptian history (BAtlas 75 E1 Memphis).

properties.title: Center of Visible Remains at Memphis

736963.title: Memphis

786017.description: Diospolis Magna/Thebai was known in ancient Egypt as Waset, "City of the Sceptre". The site was designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1979.
786017.title: Diospolis Magna/Thebai

863766.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 88 B2 Caucasus M.
863766.title: Caucasus M.

906014.description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 92 unlocated Kissia/Kissie Chore Bet Kussaye/Bakusaya
906014.title: Kissia/Kissie Chore Bet Kussaye/Bakusaya

912936.description: An ancient city of the Elamite, Persian, and Parthian empires of Iran.
912936.title: Shusha(n)/Susa/Seleucia ad Eulaeum/Shush-i er-Kar
